question: Which country was the location of the "Rose Revolution"?
explanation: The Revolution of Roses, or the Rose Revolution, was a pro-Western peaceful change of power in Georgia in November 2003. The revolution was brought about by widespread protests over the disputed parliamentary elections and culminated in the ousting of President Eduard Shevardnadze, which marked the end of the Soviet era of leadership in the country. The event derives its name from the climactic moment when demonstrators led by Mikheil Saakashvili stormed the Parliament session with red roses in hand. This revolution lasted twenty days of protests from 3 to 23 November 2003, the Revolution triggered new presidential and parliamentary elections in Georgia, which established the United National Movement as the dominant ruling party.
